Description: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, the Attorney General for the State of New York, the U.S. Secretary of Labor and the Securities and Exchange Commission announced a settlement of civil lawsuits against Bank of New York Mellon alleging that it engaged in fraud and other misconduct when providing foreign exchange services to its customers.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Company: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
Description: The Federal Reserve Board announced a $3 million fine against Bank of New York Mellon Corporation for unsafe and unsound practices after the firm improperly assigned a lower risk weighting to a portfolio of assets, reducing the firm's risk-based capital ratios.

Company: THE BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON
Description: The Federal Reserve Board issued a consent cease and desist order and assessed a $6 million civil money penalty against the Bank of New York Mellon concerning allegations that he bank breached certain representations and warranties made to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston in connection with its participation in the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility.
BNY Mellon agreed to pay a $6.6 million penalty to settle allegations stemming from miscalculations of its risk-based capital ratios and risk-weighted assets reported to investors.
The SEC announced enforcement actions against 36 municipal underwriting firms for violations in municipal bond offerings.

Mellon Bank, N.A., agreed to pay an additional $16.5 million to settle claims related to the destruction of tens of thousands of individual tax returns and checks in 2001 that the bank was supposed to process as an agent for the Treasury Department.

The Bank of New York was offered a non-prosecution agreement and agreed to pay $38 million in penalties and victim compensation to resolve parallel criminal investigations conducted by the United States Attorneys' Offices for the Eastern and Southern Districts of New York relating to BNY's responsibility for crimes involving fraud and money laundering, as well as BNY's failure to comply with mandatory reporting obligations under the Bank Secrecy Act.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Eastern District of New York

Company: Bank of New York Mellon (Shanghai Branch)

Description: The Bank of New York Mellon has agreed to repay $84 million to employee benefit plan customers who were victimized through the bank's standing instruction foreign exchange trading program.

Company: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation Foreign Exchange Transactions Litigation

Company: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
Private Litigation Case Title: Beane v. The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation et al

Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Bank of New York Mellon would pay more than $54 million to settle charges of improper handling of pre-released American Depositary Receipts (ADRs).
Allegations that bank overcharged the state for foreign currency transactions.
Info Source: Attorney General Pam Bondi Announces $28 Million Settlement with Bank of New York Mellon, Targeted News Service, November 1, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: The New York Attorney General announced that Bank of New York Mellon would pay $167.5 million to resolve allegations that it engaged in fraud and other misconduct when providing foreign exchange services to its customers. This was part of a larger $714 million settlement also involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-bank-of-new-york-mellon

Company: Bank of New York Mellon Corp.
Description: Bank of New York Mellon Corp. agreed to pay $1.2 million to New York, Texas and Florida to settle an investigation into manipulative trading of auction rate securities.

BNY Mellon Shareowner Services and Unclaimed Property Recovery & Reporting, LLC agreed to pay jointly pay $30,000 to the Commonwealth and provide full refunds to consumers in settlement of allegations they misled investors in Chevron Corp. about their rights and costs to obtain replacement stock certificates and dividend checks.
Dreyfus Corporation agreed to settle allegations that it failed to inform investors about the risks associated with one of its mutual funds.
Mellon Bank, N.A. entered into a Settlement Agreement regarding the April 2001 destruction of over 77,000 tax returns and payments at the Mellon Client Service Center in Pittsburgh.
Info Source: Mellon Bank Enters Settlement Agreemen Over Destroyed Tax Returns, US Fed News, August 18, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority reached agreements in principle with City National Securities of Beverly Hills, CA, BNY Mellon Capital Markets, LLC of New York and Harris Investor Services, Inc. of Chicago to settle charges relating to the sale of Auction Rate Securities.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.
